title: Psalms Chapter 146 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 146 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 146 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 146.

questions.question: According to Psalms 146:1, whom does the psalmist call to praise the LORD?
questions.correctAnswer: My soul
questions.explanation: Psalms 146:1 says, 'Praise ye the LORD. Praise the LORD, O my soul.' indicating the psalmist calls his own soul to praise the LORD.

questions.question: What does the psalmist say he will do while he lives in Psalms 146:2?
questions.correctAnswer: Sing praises unto God
questions.explanation: Psalms 146:2 states, 'While I live will I praise the LORD: I will sing praises unto my God while I have any being.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 146:3, in whom should you not put your trust?
questions.correctAnswer: Princes
questions.explanation: Psalms 146:3 says, 'Put not your trust in princes, nor in the son of man, in whom there is no help.'

questions.question: What happens to a man’s thoughts when his breath goes forth, according to Psalms 146:4?
questions.correctAnswer: They perish
questions.explanation: Psalms 146:4 states, 'His breath goeth forth, he returneth to his earth; in that very day his thoughts perish.'

questions.question: Who is described as happy in Psalms 146:5?
options: He that hath the God of Jacob for his help
He that is wise in his own eyes
questions.correctAnswer: He that hath the God of Jacob for his help
questions.explanation: Psalms 146:5 says, 'Happy is he that hath the God of Jacob for his help, whose hope is in the LORD his God.'

questions.question: What did the LORD make according to Psalms 146:6?
options: Heaven and earth, the sea, and all that therein is
questions.correctAnswer: Heaven and earth, the sea, and all that therein is
questions.explanation: Psalms 146:6 states, 'Which made heaven, and earth, the sea, and all that therein is.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 146:7, what does the LORD do for the oppressed?
questions.correctAnswer: Executeth judgment
questions.explanation: Psalms 146:7 says, 'Which executeth judgment for the oppressed.'

questions.question: Who does the LORD open the eyes of, as mentioned in Psalms 146:8?
questions.correctAnswer: The blind
questions.explanation: Psalms 146:8 states, 'The LORD openeth the eyes of the blind.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 146:9, whom does the LORD preserve?
questions.correctAnswer: The strangers
questions.explanation: Psalms 146:9 says, 'The LORD preserveth the strangers; he relieveth the fatherless and widow.'

questions.question: What does the LORD do to the way of the wicked according to Psalms 146:9?
questions.correctAnswer: Turns it upside down
questions.explanation: Psalms 146:9 states, 'but the way of the wicked he turneth upside down.'

questions.question: For how long shall the LORD reign according to Psalms 146:10?
options: Until the end of the age
questions.correctAnswer: Forever
questions.explanation: Psalms 146:10 says, 'The LORD shall reign for ever.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 146:3 says to put your trust in sons of man.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 146:3 clearly says, 'Put not your trust in princes, nor in the son of man, in whom there is no help.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 146:8 states that the LORD loveth the righteous.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 146:8 says, 'The LORD loveth the righteous.'

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 146:4, a man's thoughts continue after his breath goes forth.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 146:4 says, 'His breath goeth forth...in that very day his thoughts perish.'

questions.question: Complete this verse from Psalms 146:7: 'The LORD looseth the ______.'
questions.correctAnswer: prisoners
questions.explanation: Psalms 146:7 states, 'The LORD looseth the prisoners.'

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 146 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 146 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with trusting human leaders during difficult times. Based on Psalms 146, what biblical truth would you share?
options: Trust not in princes or sons of man, for they cannot help
Pray only to human leaders for guidance
Rely solely on your own strength
Ignore God and trust in wealth
questions.correctAnswer: Trust not in princes or sons of man, for they cannot help
questions.explanation: Psalms 146:3 teaches us not to put our trust in princes or the son of man, because they offer no lasting help. This encourages believers to place their trust in God alone (verses 5, 10).

questions.question: How does Psalms 146 instruct believers to respond in their daily living regarding praise?
options: Praise the LORD continually while you live
Praise only during times of prosperity
questions.correctAnswer: Praise the LORD continually while you live
questions.explanation: Verses 1 and 2 emphasize praising the LORD with all our soul and singing praises to God as long as we live, highlighting continual worship and devotion.

questions.question: What does Psalms 146 teach about God’s care for the vulnerable in society?
options: The LORD executes judgment for the oppressed and cares for the hungry
The LORD favors the wealthy alone
The LORD only helps those who can repay Him
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD executes judgment for the oppressed and cares for the hungry
questions.explanation: Verse 7 highlights God's active role in delivering justice for the oppressed and providing food for the hungry, showing His care for society’s vulnerable.

questions.question: If a believer feels overwhelmed by personal trials, what encouragement does Psalms 146 offer about God’s power and faithfulness?
options: God made the heavens, earth, and sea and keeps truth forever
God will abandon you during trials
questions.correctAnswer: God made the heavens, earth, and sea and keeps truth forever
questions.explanation: Verse 6 reminds believers that God, the Creator of all, maintains truth eternally, assuring us of His unchanging faithfulness during hardships.

questions.question: According to Psalms 146, how should believers view the temporary nature of human life and plans?
options: Human breath departs and thoughts perish the same day
Human life is eternal without God
Ignore the fleeting nature of life
questions.correctAnswer: Human breath departs and thoughts perish the same day
questions.explanation: Verse 4 teaches that human life is temporary and mortal, urging trust in God rather than in fleeting human strength or plans.

questions.question: How does Psalms 146 encourage believers to serve their church and community?
options: By trusting God to act justly and helping the oppressed and needy
By focusing only on personal gain
By ignoring the needs of others
questions.correctAnswer: By trusting God to act justly and helping the oppressed and needy
questions.explanation: Verses 7-9 show God’s concern for the oppressed, hungry, blind, and fatherless, inspiring believers to reflect this care through service.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to despair over injustice. What biblical truth from Psalms 146 can you share to encourage perseverance?
options: The LORD reigns forever and will overturn the way of the wicked
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD reigns forever and will overturn the way of the wicked
questions.explanation: Verse 10 affirms God’s eternal reign and that He will upset the plans of the wicked, encouraging believers to trust God’s justice.

questions.question: How does Psalms 146 encourage believers to maintain integrity and hope in their relationship with God?
options: Happy is the one who has the God of Jacob for help and whose hope is in the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: Happy is the one who has the God of Jacob for help and whose hope is in the LORD
questions.explanation: Verse 5 teaches that true happiness and hope come from relying on God, promoting integrity and trust in Him rather than worldly things.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 146 teaches that God only helps those who are righteous and ignores the strangers and widows.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 9 clearly states that the LORD preserves strangers, and relieves the fatherless and widow, showing His care extends beyond just the righteous.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 146 encourages believers to sing praises to God only when they feel happy and successful.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verses 1-2 emphasize praising the LORD throughout life, regardless of circumstances, encouraging continuous worship.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: "The LORD openeth the eyes of the _____; the LORD raiseth them that are bowed down."
questions.correctAnswer: blind
questions.explanation: Verse 8 teaches that the LORD opens the eyes of the blind and lifts up those who are bowed down, showing His power to restore and encourage.

questions.question: How does Psalms 146 illustrate God’s faithfulness in times of hardship for families and individuals?
options: God preserves strangers and relieves the fatherless and widow
God favors only the wealthy families
questions.correctAnswer: God preserves strangers and relieves the fatherless and widow
questions.explanation: Verse 9 highlights God's care for vulnerable family members, showing His faithfulness and encouraging believers to trust Him in hardship.

questions.question: What does Psalms 146 teach about humility and contentment in daily life?
options: Rely on God who raises the humble and cares for the oppressed
Seek power and riches above all
Ignore the needs of the poor
questions.correctAnswer: Rely on God who raises the humble and cares for the oppressed
questions.explanation: Verses 7-8 describe God’s actions in lifting the bowed down and helping the oppressed, encouraging humility and contentment through reliance on God.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with forgiveness and reconciliation. Based on Psalms 146, what principle could guide their attitude?
options: Trust in the LORD’s justice and love for the righteous
questions.correctAnswer: Trust in the LORD’s justice and love for the righteous
questions.explanation: Verse 8 shows the LORD loves the righteous and executes judgment for the oppressed, encouraging believers to rely on God’s justice rather than personal vengeance.

questions.question: How does Psalms 146 encourage believers in their work ethic and daily integrity?
options: Place hope in God who keeps truth forever
questions.correctAnswer: Place hope in God who keeps truth forever
questions.explanation: Verse 6 emphasizes God’s eternal truth and faithfulness, encouraging believers to live honestly and trust God in their work and life.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 146 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 146.

questions.question: In Psalms 146:3, why does the psalmist advise against putting trust in princes or the son of man?
options: Because they have no lasting power or help
questions.correctAnswer: Because they have no lasting power or help
questions.explanation: Psalms 146:3 states that princes and the son of man provide no help, highlighting human frailty and impermanence as reasons not to trust them.

questions.question: Which theme in Psalms 146:6 connects to the creation narratives found in Genesis 1?
options: The LORD made heaven, earth, and sea
The LORD opens the eyes of the blind
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD made heaven, earth, and sea
questions.explanation: Psalms 146:6 alludes to the creative acts described in Genesis 1, emphasizing God as Creator of all things, establishing a foundational theological theme.

questions.question: What literary device is evident in Psalms 146:7 where multiple acts of the LORD are listed in parallel?
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism
questions.explanation: Psalms 146:7 uses parallelism, a common Hebrew poetry device, listing actions of God in balanced phrases to emphasize His justice and care.

questions.question: The phrase 'The LORD openeth the eyes of the blind' in Psalms 146:8 serves as a typological foreshadowing of which New Testament event?
options: Jesus healing the blind in the Gospels
Pentecost and the outpouring of the Spirit
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus healing the blind in the Gospels
questions.explanation: Psalms 146:8 foreshadows God's restoration of sight, typologically fulfilled in Jesus' miracles healing the blind in the New Testament.

questions.question: According to Psalms 146:5, what is the source of true happiness?
options: Having the God of Jacob for help
questions.correctAnswer: Having the God of Jacob for help
questions.explanation: Psalms 146:5 declares that happiness comes from trusting in the LORD, the God of Jacob, highlighting reliance on divine help over worldly power.

questions.question: How does the concept of divine justice in Psalms 146:7 relate to social justice themes in the prophetic books like Isaiah?
options: Both emphasize God's care for the oppressed and needy
Both reject the idea of God's eternal reign
questions.correctAnswer: Both emphasize God's care for the oppressed and needy
questions.explanation: Psalms 146:7's focus on God executing judgment for the oppressed parallels Isaiah's calls for justice and care for the marginalized.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Psalms 146:10 proclaims that the LORD shall reign _______.
questions.correctAnswer: forever
questions.explanation: Psalms 146:10 explicitly states that the LORD shall reign forever, emphasizing God's eternal sovereignty.

questions.question: What cultural context helps explain the warning against trusting princes in Psalms 146:3?
options: Ancient Near Eastern kings were often unreliable and mortal
questions.correctAnswer: Ancient Near Eastern kings were often unreliable and mortal
questions.explanation: In the ancient Near East, human rulers were mortal and fallible, so the psalmist warns in Psalms 146:3 against placing ultimate trust in them.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 146 emphasizes God's care for both the fatherless and the widow as an expression of His justice.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 146:9 specifically mentions God's care for the fatherless and widow, highlighting His concern for vulnerable groups.

questions.question: How does the phrase 'he returneth to his earth; in that very day his thoughts perish' in Psalms 146:4 reflect ancient Hebrew anthropology?
options: It reflects the belief that human life is transient and mortal
It suggests humans become divine after death
It denies the existence of an afterlife
questions.correctAnswer: It reflects the belief that human life is transient and mortal
questions.explanation: Psalms 146:4 articulates the ancient Hebrew view that humans are mortal with fleeting thoughts, emphasizing reliance on God rather than human strength.

questions.question: Which Hebrew word concept related to 'truth' in Psalms 146:6 underscores God's faithfulness throughout generations?
questions.correctAnswer: Emet (truth)
questions.explanation: Psalms 146:6 uses a word translated as 'truth' reflecting the Hebrew concept 'Emet,' which conveys God's unchanging faithfulness.

questions.question: What is the significance of the psalmist’s personal commitment expressed in Psalms 146:2?
options: A lifelong dedication to praise God while alive
Praise limited to the temple rituals
questions.correctAnswer: A lifelong dedication to praise God while alive
questions.explanation: Psalms 146:2 demonstrates a personal vow to continually praise God for as long as the psalmist lives, reflecting devotion and trust.

questions.question: In Psalms 146:9, what is meant by 'the way of the wicked he turneth upside down'?
options: God frustrates the plans of the wicked
questions.correctAnswer: God frustrates the plans of the wicked
questions.explanation: Psalms 146:9 indicates that God actively opposes and overturns the schemes of the wicked, demonstrating divine justice.

questions.question: How does Psalms 146:10’s declaration about God’s reign function as an eschatological statement?
options: It proclaims God’s eternal kingship extending beyond present time
It limits God’s reign to David’s dynasty
It refers only to earthly kings
questions.correctAnswer: It proclaims God’s eternal kingship extending beyond present time
questions.explanation: Psalms 146:10 asserts God's eternal reign, which is an eschatological theme pointing to ultimate divine sovereignty over all generations.

questions.question: True or False: The psalmist’s praise in Psalms 146:1 is directed both to the LORD and the psalmist’s own soul.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 146:1 calls for praise to the LORD and commands the psalmist's own soul to praise Him, showing an internal and external call to worship.

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 146 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 146 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Psalms 146:3, why should one not put trust in princes or the son of man?
options: Because in them there is no help
questions.correctAnswer: Because in them there is no help
questions.explanation: Psalms 146:3 states explicitly that princes and the son of man offer no help. This reflects the biblical teaching that ultimate trust should be placed in God alone (Jeremiah 17:5; Psalm 118:8; Isaiah 2:22; Matthew 6:24).

questions.question: What happens to man’s thoughts when his breath departs, according to Psalms 146:4?
options: His thoughts are recorded in heaven
questions.correctAnswer: His thoughts perish
questions.explanation: Psalms 146:4 teaches that when a man dies, his thoughts perish with him, emphasizing human mortality and the futility of trusting in human strength (Ecclesiastes 3:19-21; Job 14:10-12; James 4:14; Psalm 39:5).

questions.question: Who is described as 'happy' in Psalms 146:5?
options: He that hath the God of Jacob for his help
questions.correctAnswer: He that hath the God of Jacob for his help
questions.explanation: The psalm declares happiness for those who rely on God as their help and place their hope in Him, aligning with other biblical affirmations of blessedness in trusting God (Psalm 1:1-3; Jeremiah 17:7; Matthew 5:3-6; Romans 15:13).

questions.question: What works of creation are attributed to the LORD in Psalms 146:6?
options: He made heaven, earth, sea, and all that is therein
He made only the earth and sea
questions.correctAnswer: He made heaven, earth, sea, and all that is therein
questions.explanation: Psalms 146:6 attributes the entire cosmos to God’s creative power, affirming His sovereignty over all creation, consistent with Genesis 1:1; Nehemiah 9:6; Colossians 1:16; Revelation 4:11.

questions.question: According to Psalms 146:7, which acts of justice and mercy does the LORD perform?
options: He executes judgment for the oppressed and gives food to the hungry
He judges the wicked and punishes the proud
He blesses the rich and prospers the righteous
He punishes sinners and ignores the poor
questions.correctAnswer: He executes judgment for the oppressed and gives food to the hungry
questions.explanation: This verse highlights God's active justice and mercy on behalf of the oppressed and hungry, consistent with Isaiah 1:17; Proverbs 31:8-9; Luke 4:18; James 1:27.

questions.question: Who does the LORD open the eyes of and raise up, as stated in Psalms 146:8?
options: The blind and those who are bowed down
questions.correctAnswer: The blind and those who are bowed down
questions.explanation: Psalms 146:8 shows God's compassion in restoring those who are physically and spiritually impaired, in line with Isaiah 35:5; John 9:1-3; Luke 1:52; Matthew 11:5.

questions.question: In Psalms 146:9, how does the LORD treat strangers, fatherless, and widows?
questions.correctAnswer: He preserves and relieves them
questions.explanation: The psalm affirms God’s care for vulnerable groups, consistent with Exodus 22:22-24; Deuteronomy 10:18; James 1:27; Psalm 68:5.

questions.question: What ultimate destiny does the LORD promise for the wicked in Psalms 146:9?
options: He turns their way upside down
questions.correctAnswer: He turns their way upside down
questions.explanation: The LORD’s judgment on the wicked is to overturn their plans and ways, reflecting divine justice (Proverbs 3:33; Psalm 37:28; Isaiah 13:11; Romans 1:18).

questions.question: What eternal role does the LORD have according to Psalms 146:10?
options: He shall judge only the wicked
questions.correctAnswer: He shall reign forever
questions.explanation: The LORD’s eternal reign is affirmed here, corresponding to Daniel 4:3; 1 Chronicles 29:10; Revelation 11:15; Isaiah 9:7.

questions.question: How does Psalms 146:1 describe the attitude of the psalmist toward the LORD?
options: Praise the LORD, O my soul
Fear the LORD, O my soul
Question the LORD, O my soul
Ignore the LORD, O my soul
questions.correctAnswer: Praise the LORD, O my soul
questions.explanation: The psalmist calls the soul to praise God, highlighting worship as a fundamental response, consistent with Psalm 103:1; Isaiah 61:3; Hebrews 13:15; Revelation 19:5.

questions.question: What commitment does the psalmist make in Psalms 146:2 regarding praise?
options: To praise the LORD while he lives
To praise only in temple worship
To praise only on holy days
questions.correctAnswer: To praise the LORD while he lives
questions.explanation: The psalmist commits to lifelong praise, underscoring continual worship (Psalm 34:1; Psalm 71:14; Luke 1:46-47; Philippians 4:4).

questions.question: Which attribute of God is emphasized in Psalms 146:6 by stating 'He keepeth truth forever'?
questions.correctAnswer: God’s faithfulness and eternal truth
questions.explanation: This verse teaches God’s unchanging faithfulness and truthfulness, consistent with Numbers 23:19; Psalm 89:14; John 14:6; Hebrews 6:18.

questions.question: What liberation does the LORD provide according to Psalms 146:7?
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD looseth the prisoners
questions.explanation: God is depicted as a liberator of those in bondage, aligning with Isaiah 61:1; Luke 4:18; Psalm 107:14; Acts 16:25-34.

questions.question: Who does the LORD love according to Psalms 146:8?
questions.correctAnswer: The righteous
questions.explanation: The LORD’s love is directed toward the righteous, consistent with Psalm 97:10; Proverbs 3:32; Matthew 5:6; Romans 12:9.

questions.question: How does Psalms 146 portray the basis for hope and help in life?
options: Hope and help are in the LORD, not in humans
Hope and help come from wealth
Hope and help come from political power
Hope and help come from human wisdom
questions.correctAnswer: Hope and help are in the LORD, not in humans
questions.explanation: The psalm contrasts human frailty with God’s eternal help and hope (Psalm 146:3-5), consistent with Isaiah 40:31; Jeremiah 17:7; Hebrews 6:19; 2 Corinthians 1:10.
